{{stub}} '''Ilu''' is a [[Quenya]] word that means "all, everything, the world". As a cosmological term it includes everything that exists, the created being ([[Eä]]) but also [[God]] and the [[spirits]] who created it, and all [[fëa|souls]].{{VT|39a}}, p. 20 ==Other versions of the legendarium== {{quote|Ilu [[Ilúvatar]] en káre [[Eldar|eldain]] a [[Fírimar|fírimoin]].
([[Qenya]]: The Father made the World for Elves and Mortals)|[[Fíriel's song]]{{LR|P1III2}}}} In the early concept of the [[legendarium]], ''Ilu'' was the name of "the World", signifying ''both'' the inhabited world and also the whole universe. Ilu is everything that exists, and comprises of the habitable world proper ([[Ambar]]), with its layers of air and skies, the [[Sun]], the [[Moon]] and the [[stars]]. All these are enveloped in the outer layer of air, [[Vaiya]]. The boundaries of Ilu are the [[Ilurambar]], the "shell" that encloses Ilu, separating Vaiya from [[kúma]] and non-existence.{{SM|5}} This concept evolved in a different cosmology in ''[[The Later Quenta Silmarillion]]'', where new concepts are introduced: The habitable world is named ''[[Arda]]'', more or less equivalent to both [[Ambar]] and Ilu; the whole existence, or created universe, is named ''[[Eä]]'', which, unlike the former Ilu, is vast and might include other worlds other than Arda.{{S|Ainu}} ==Etymology== The word ''Ilu'' is [[Quenya]] and means "universe", and is an alternative form of ''[[ilúvë]]''. They come from the [[root]] [[IL]] meaning "all".{{LR|Etymologies}} Ilu does not appear in the published [[Silmarillion]], but the alternate form ''[[ilúvë]]'' survives, as in the name ''[[Ilúvatar]]''.{{S|Appendix}}, ''ilúvë'' ==Inspiration== [[Christopher Gilson]] has noted that the name ''Ilu'' is presumably inspired by the [[Wikipedia:Akkadian|Akkadian]] word ''ilu'' ("gods").[[Christopher Gilson]], "His Breath Was Taken Away: Tolkien, Barfield, and Elvish Diction", in {{TS|14}}, p. 41 {{references}} {{cosmology}} [[Category:Cosmology]] [[Category:Quenya nouns]]
